revised_title: Effects of Catecholamines on Tension Reactivation in Cardiac Muscle
tldr: The study investigates the effects of adrenaline and isoprenaline on tension reactivation in cardiac muscle. It explores the role of the sarcoplasmic reticulum in reactivation of tension and how catecholamines may affect calcium recycling. The results show that catecholamines can enhance tension reactivation, and the effects vary depending on the species and the amount of sarcoplasmic reticulum in the cardiac tissue. This research helps understand the control of tension production by calcium and its relation to the timing of activation in the cardiac cycle.
